Six people talk about their typical working day. Each person has a different job and responsibilities.
A. Credit Card Executive: Manages all customer development programmes for regular credit card users. Launches and manages the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. Keeps in touch with existing card users, acquires new ones, and builds relationships with partner companies.
B. Record Company Executive: Deals with demo tapes, letters, invoices, and meetings related to artists and campaigns. Is aware of the sound quality and tries to be constructive. Starts and completes the first album for a band, including choosing songs, producer, and musicians. Oversees budgets and spending.
C. Sales Director: Opens the post, checks the diary, and waits for clients. Loves taking people round the showrooms and selling furniture. Buys and sells antiques. Liaises with gilders, picture framers, and paper repairers.
D. Air Traffic Controller: Works a set shift pattern and controls aircraft movements. Deals with a high volume of movements in summer. Can be stressful and difficult to wind down.
E. Shop Manager: Gets the point-of-sale system up and running, helps customers, and orders books. Can be annoying if customers come in with unrealistic expectations.
F. Financial Analyst: Provides financial risk assessments for multi-national companies. Travels to Africa three times a year. Can be difficult to switch off and often stays awake late.

Career Power Get the leading edge - motivate yourself to take full control at work.
A good leader is one who inspires, motivates, and encourages others. To be a good leader, you need to be able to speak clearly and articulately, have confidence in your abilities, and be able to inspire others. You also need to be able to set goals and achieve them.
There are a few things you can do to improve your leadership skills. First, find out where your passions and convictions lie and start thinking of yourself as a leader. Second, learn how to delegate and motivate others, organise and chastise, praise and raise. Third, keep working on your communication skills. Finally, remember that leadership does not simply happen. It can only develop from actually taking the lead, from taking risks and learning from mistakes.

Films on video are a popular way to enjoy movies. There are many different types of films available on video, including action, comedy, drama, and horror. Some of the most popular films on video include A Abyss Long Before Titanic, The Thin Red Line, On Guard, and The Good, the Bad and the Ugly.
These films are all very different from each other. A Abyss Long Before Titanic is a Cold War thriller about oil riggers and navy experts trying to rescue a nuclear submarine stranded many miles beneath water. The Thin Red Line is a war movie about the battle for Guadalcanal. On Guard is a swashbuckler movie about a group of musketeers. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly is a spaghetti western about the post-Civil War West.
Each film has its own unique strengths and weaknesses. A Abyss Long Before Titanic has impressive production design and special effects, but the dialogue and characterisation are creaky. The Thin Red Line has a mystical and poetic approach, but it lacks moments. On Guard has a lot of action and excitement, but the story is corny. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly has excellent sound editing and Morricone's magnificent music, but the storytelling is relentless and cruel.
Overall, there are many different types of films available on video. Each film has its own unique strengths and weaknesses. However, there is a film for everyone to enjoy.

Steve Martin's book, "Compelling Evidence," is a compelling read. The narrator, a lawyer, finds himself defending his boss's wife when she is tried for her husband's murder. The trial scenes are exciting, with the outcome in doubt right up to the verdict. This book is a terrific debut into a crowded genre.
Curtains for the Cardinal, by Faye Kellermann, is another book that is worth reading. It is a complex plot with a lot of characters. However, it is still a great book.
File Under: Deceased, by Sarah Lacey, is a refreshing detective novel. It introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, who is gutsy and versatile. The book is well-written and entertaining.
Double Deuce, by Robert B. Parker, is a high-quality entertainment book. It features Spenser, a literate private investigator, and Hawk, his friend. The book is full of action and philosophy.
False Prophet, by Faye Kellermann, is another entertaining mystery. It features Pete Decker and Marge Dunn, two detectives who investigate an attack and burglary at the house of a legendary film star's daughter. The book is well-written and engaging.

Tim Pozzi, a 34-year-old, decided to go backpacking this summer. He was inspired by others who had taken the plunge and felt that it was time for him to do the same. He was nervous about leaving his job and his routine, but he knew that he had to do it.
There are many reasons why people choose to travel in their late twenties and thirties. Some people want to have a final fling before settling down, while others want to temper their approach to life and get rid of their old habits. Still others want to reassess their lives and take a step back to think about their future.
There are also a number of factors that make it easier for people to travel in their late twenties and thirties. The workforce is more flexible today, and there are more people working on short-term contracts. Larger companies are even adopting career-break policies.
Whether you're young or old, there are many benefits to travelling. It can be a chance to learn new things, meet new people, and experience new cultures. It can also be a chance to take a break from your routine and reflect on your life.

The computer has helped me in many ways. I used to work at a desk that was always a mess, and I was always losing scraps of paper containing vital bits of information. Now, I have a computer that helps me to be more organized. Spreadsheets help me to keep track of my income and expenses, and pre-formatted invoices and letterheads have saved me a lot of time and effort. I also use the Internet to research stories, ask for further information, and discuss the pros and cons of working from home with people from all over the world.
However, there are also some challenges associated with working from home. You can be in isolation from physical human contact, and there are the distractions of putting urgent jobs about the house first. But, there are also a growing number of people who have recently bought multi-media PCs, not just for the educational, leisure and entertainment facilities. In my street alone, there appears to be a new type of technical cottage industry evolving from the sheer convenience of not having to join the commuter struggle into the city each day.

The Tartan Museum is a modern museum in Scotland. It has a lot of interesting objects. The museum is located in Edinburgh, a historic city. The museum building is very impressive. It has a huge, yellow sandstone tower and cheese-wedge buildings.
The museum has a lot of exhibitions. There are stories about the history of Scotland. There are also stories about the people who lived in Scotland. The museum has a lot of beautiful objects. There are jewels, silver, and other treasures.
The museum also has a Discovery Centre. It is a place where children can learn about the history of Scotland. The Discovery Centre has a lot of interactive games and activities.
Overall, the Tartan Museum is a very interesting place. It is a must-see for anyone who is visiting Scotland.

The end of print may take some time. It's a pleasant word and a calming concept. Change may frighten some and challenge others, but transition means going surely and sweetly from somewhere present to somewhere future. Newspapers are facing a decline in sales, but their websites are going ever higher. The latest print circulation figures show that sales are plummeting, but the websites of The Daily Telegraph, The Guardian and many of the rest are up. The decline in sales is due to a number of factors, including timing, demography, geography and more. However, the latest survey of trends by the World Association of Newspapers shows that global circulation rose 1.1% last year. Sales in the West dropped back but Asia more than made up the difference. Books are also facing a decline in sales, but e-readers are booming. The best way to attract a paying readership appears to be a deal that offers the print copy and digital access as some kind of joint package.

People are the most interesting subjects for photographs. A photograph with someone in it is usually more compelling than the same shot without the human interest. People are also the most difficult subjects to photograph well. To take good pictures of people, you need to be aware of actions, gestures and expressions. And often the presence of the camera itself can have a disastrous effect on these.
To improve your pictures of people, you can follow these tips:
* Group people in different ways to create interest.
* Help people relax and pose naturally.
* Make sure the subject is not overwhelmed by the background.
* Use eye contact or gestures to connect with the viewer.
* Show expressions and emotions through gestures and facial expressions.
* Use the background to add interest and information about the subject.
* Include interaction between people in your pictures.
* Take pictures of people in their environment to show where they were.
* Balance the subjects and the place they were visiting in your picture.
* Decide whether you want to pose or not pose the subject.

Sarah Janson is an artist who creates illusions of reality through her paintings. She is not interested in being known as the artist who created the work, but rather the artist who made it possible. Janson has been painting for sixteen years and has a string of major corporate and private commissions behind her. Much of her work is inspired by architecture or made for architectural settings.
Janson's paintings are unique and can be seen in a league of their own. They are often inspired by architecture and give the illusion that you can step into another room. However, there is also a danger with trompe-l'oeil that once you get the joke, your attention is lost.
Janson is generous in praise of her clients and is always willing to listen to their ideas. She is also very friendly and has a strong rapport with her clients. Many have become friends with her, and they all seem delighted with her work.

In the workplace, emotional intelligence (EQ) is becoming increasingly important. It is the ability to monitor and regulate one's own and others' feelings, and to use feelings to guide thought and action. EQ comprises basic elements such as self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy and adeptness in social relationships.
More and more businesses are seeing that encouraging EQ skills is a valuable component of management philosophy. If you have strong EQ skills, you are more likely to be successful in your job and in every part of the world.
There are many examples of people who have risen to the top notwithstanding flaws in emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex and collaborative, companies where people work together best have a competitive edge. In the new workplace, with its emphasis on teamwork and a strong customer orientation, EQ is becoming increasingly essential for excellence in every job.

**
Should the media earn money from content they don't own? Although it is easier to capture newsworthy events with digital cameras and camera phones, social media has revolutionised citizen photography. With news regularly breaking on social networks, some journalists are now turning to them as sources of images as fast-moving events occur. Unfortunately, some reporters have published user-generated content (UGC) without permission. Despite official guidance that images posted on social media can be used without permission if there are exceptional circumstances or strong public interest, debate continues about whether this is ethical. With research indicating that a significant number of people would film or photograph a news event, it is clear that UGC has a major role to play in the future of the media. However, if the media is to prevent its relationship with the public from souring, steps must be taken to ensure that people are properly rewarded for their work and that permission is always sought.

Ancient Chinese medicine, also known as acupuncture, is a traditional Chinese system of medicine that has been used for centuries. It is used to treat many different conditions, but acupuncture's role in treating pain has been the most attention.
Acupuncture points are related to meridians, which are lines of energy that flow through the body. When the flow of energy is disrupted, the body becomes unbalanced and can become weak or sick.
To treat pain, acupuncturists use fine needles inserted into the skin. They may also apply warmth from smouldering herbs or pressure at points on meridians.
Acupuncture can be effective for treating a variety of pain conditions, including back pain, arthritis, headaches, and migraines. It is also sometimes used to treat other conditions, such as menstrual pain and facial nerve pain.
It is important to note that acupuncture is not a substitute for medical treatment. If you are experiencing pain, you should consult with a doctor to see if acupuncture might be right for you.

P. D. James, a best-selling crime writer, is known for her complex and brilliant imagination. She exudes an air of quiet authority and is often described as shyer than she appears. Her novels have been read avidly by millions all over the world. She is a great fan of the works of close friend Ruth Rendell and enjoys reading detective stories.
James was born in Oxford and grew up mainly in Cambridge. She worked full-time in administration for the National Health Service and made good use of her organizational skills. She became 'quite accustomed' to seeing corpses while working in forensic science. But it was not fascination with death itself that inspired her. It was, rather, the shape and construction involved in the writing of a crime novel that appealed.
James's success came late in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel, Cover Her Face, was published. Despite her challenges, she became a successful writer and her novels are enjoyed by people all over the world.

The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is accepted as a genuine science in many countries. It can be used to indicate certain illnesses, such as heart disease and cancer, and can reveal psychological states and emotional disturbances. Many big companies now employ graphologists to analyse the handwriting of potential candidates for key jobs.
Handwriting can also be used to predict would-be suicides and other psychological characteristics. People with writing in which letters form 'threads' instead of being individually forms are, apparently, devious and clever. Those who write mainly in capitals are trying to conceal their true selves from others. Disconnected writing is the cardinal sign of the loner.
It takes six years of study and experience to be able to analyse handwriting accurately. To be able to use graphology effectively, you also need empathy and intuition. More research is needed to put graphology on a proper scientific footing.

Is your office working ok? Fresh air and comfortable chairs are the key to a happy, healthy workforce, according to a new survey. We went to four different offices to find out how healthy and happy they were as working environments. We had an expert panel of a building health consultant, an ergonomist, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their verdicts.
Office A is a small office with a lot of natural light. The employees are happy and healthy, but the office is not very comfortable. Office B is a comfortable office with good air quality and plenty of space. However, the office is a bit impersonal and unstimulating. Office C is a busy office with a lot of activity. The employees are well-served by technology, but the office is not very comfortable. Office D is a dusty office with a lot of problems. The employees are stressed and driven by deadlines, but the office is not very comfortable.

Chewing gum is a popular fashion accessory in the United States. Americans chew 12 million sticks of gum a day. Gum is made from a natural substance called chicle, which is obtained from the sapodilla tree. In the past, people chewed gum made from the bark of trees. Today, most gum is made synthetically. Gum can help to reduce tooth decay. It also helps to increase salivary flow.

The Ghanerao Hotel in India and the Hermitage Hotel in New Zealand are two charming hotels. The Ghanerao Hotel is located in a small rural village and offers a tranquil atmosphere. The Hermitage Hotel is situated in the most beautiful countryside and provides extreme luxury.
The Paradis Hotel on Mauritius is another isolated hotel. It offers a private beach and a quiet environment. The Ladera Hotel in St. Lucia has a dramatic setting and provides a colonial-style atmosphere. The Splendid Hotel in Istanbul is a historic hotel with a unique charm.
The Fairview Hotel in Kenya is a comfortable and affordable hotel. It offers a peaceful atmosphere and beautiful gardens. The Hotel Splendido in Portofinto is a historic hotel with a glamorous past. It offers stunning views and delicious food.

The hotel inspector Sue Brown judges hotels for a living. One day, she was inspecting the Globe Hotel. Things were not going well from the beginning. The receptionist was not aware of the guest she was ignoring. Sue was not impressed with the hotel's rating or the service. She also found a large hole in the wall. However, she did praise the assistant manager and the waitress for their hospitality. Dinner was also good. Sue is required to write a report about her findings. She sends it to the hotelier. The hotelier is glad that Sue is not going to recommend that the Globe be stripped of its red stars. But he knows that another inspector will be back to make sure that everything has been put right.

Seven Up Mountaineer Doug Scott shares his experience of conquering the highest peak on each continent, the Seven Summits. My quest to climb the Seven Summits came late in life. I climbed the Seven Summits in the order I completed them.
A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)
I was in a snow cave below the summit when I started talking to my feet. The cold was getting into my feet and I recalled other climbers who had lost fingers and toes from frostbite.
B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)
This mountain is regarded as the most treacherous in the world. We followed a new route and spent a lot of time on the ridge.
C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,89Sm)
We got lost in the dense jungles and ran out of water. We found a rock pool and spent the night there.
D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)
The original route up Aconcagua is little more than a walk. We decided to miss out on the glacier and go across the north ridges.
E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)
When I learned that climbing Vinson Massif was just a matter of guiding enough people, attempting all of the Seven Summits became a reality.
F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)
We walked to the refuge and crossed open slopes. We reached what we thought was the summit, but there was another kilometre-long ridge to the actual summit.
G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)
We climbed in rock shoes and reached the summit. I was given a standing ovation on this, my seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

Style Merchants Style is a company that provides information about the latest fashion trends. Jo Foley, Ned Ingham, Sally Quail, Lily Grimson, and Peter Little are some of the designers whose work is featured on the company's website.
Ned Ingham designs wedding dresses. He believes that simpler styles are more flattering than traditional, stiff dresses and frilly looks. He has been drawing and designing wedding dresses since he was a schoolboy.
Sally Quail is a jeweller who designs necklaces, bracelets, and rings. She started designing her own pieces when she couldn't find an engagement ring she liked. Her pieces are sought out by many stars of stage and screen.
Lily Grimson designs handbags. Her bags are handmade in the UK and are full of glamour.
Peter Little is a hairdresser who has styled hair for many celebrities. He believes that real-looking hair and a style that can be managed at home are important to his clients.
Penny Pratt is a florist who has been successful in the flower business. She has no floristry qualifications and gave up her job as a teacher in order to do 'something different'.

The Merrion Hotel is a five-star hotel that has recently opened in Dublin. It is a new hotel that has been created using four large eighteenth-century houses. The hotel has a lot of technology, including a computer system that can deal with return clients and a system that controls room temperature. The hotel also has a lot of amenities, such as a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants.
The Merrion Hotel is likely to be successful because of its technology, its amenities, and its highly capable staff.

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. There is a harmony of colour, shape and structure in the flower borders that line the paved path. Much of this is due to the previous owners who were keen gardeners. Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. More usually, she picks them and then takes them up to her studio. Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips and poppies are out. She has a come-what-may attitude to the garden, rather like an affectionate aunt who is quite happy for children to run about undisciplined.

No title. Many trees in the Brackham area were blown down in a terrible storm that March. The town itself lost two great lime trees from the former market square. The disappearance of such prominent features had altered the appearance of the town centre entirely. Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, head of the local police force, was annoyed by the change. He was sick with bronchitis and couldn't concentrate on his work. His wife, Molly, tried to persuade him to go to the doctor, but he refused. He eventually went to the doctor and was prescribed antibiotics. The loss of the trees made a permanent difference to the appearance of the living-room. The room seemed cruelly bright and the worn furnishings were exposed in all their shabbiness.

We lived in a valley for sixteen months. The snow and wind were very strong that winter. The river was also very wild. It threatened to flood our home. But the dam held the water back and prevented the flood. We can now enjoy the beautiful clouds and the powerful river without fear.

Film critic Mark Adams has been writing articles about films for a newspaper called The Front Page for the last ten years. He started writing articles about films before he had a proper job. He met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also wrote for radio and television. Tom hired Mark, but he was not primarily a journalist. He had a lot of ideas for the newspaper, but they didn't all work out. The general public preferred to associate a reviewer with a single subject area. Mark chose film as his subject area. He likes the space he has to broaden his argument. He doesn't feel he has a responsibility to be 'right' about a movie. All he has to do is put forward an argument.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km and then run 1Okm? Because it's fun. A teenager with a taste for endurance wanted: Sports-mad training partner for triathlete, preferably female. The triathlon promises to be one of the most popular Olympic sports. Recently it has drawn huge crowds fascinated (and horrified) by athletes swimming 1500m, cycling 40km, then running 1Okm without stopping.
Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. She won the junior section - but then she was the only junior taking part. She was determined to work hard and achieve her goals. She is trying to talk her parents into buying her a new bike so she can try national 25 km and 100 km races later this year. But there is another price to pay. Her punishing training sessions have made her a bit of a recluse.

The Collectors Amanda Roy writes about the things she collects and why people enjoy collecting. Collecting is a world of passion, envy and enthusiasm. If you enter this world, remember one thing: you must fall in love with an object before you collect it. People have been collecting things since the beginning of time. Some people collect stones and seashells just for the beauty of their forms and colours. Others collect flowers, paintings or pottery. If you want to start a collection, you do not have to be rich or powerful. You can start with small items, such as tulip bulbs or china cups. You can also collect toys or other items that you enjoy.

Four people talk about their jobs. Lisa is an Exhibition Programmes Organiser at the Science Museum. She is responsible for putting together temporary exhibitions. This includes planning, designing, and promoting the exhibition. She has to read up about the subject of the exhibition and talk to important people in the area. She also has to make sure the public can understand the thinking behind the exhibition.
Janet is a Teacher of London Taxi Drivers. She checks accounts and sees what new maps and documents need to be produced. She then teaches students how to make the journeys. She gets involved when there's a difference of opinion and tells students to use another route.
Sarah is a Marine Conservationist. She lives by the coast and works from home. She responds to telephone enquiries, produces educational resources, and sets up training courses. She also works with schools and study centres and runs courses for coastal managers and those involved in making decisions about the fate of the seas.
Chris is a Map and Atlas Publisher. He has to make sure that the publishing programme matches market requirements and ensure that there are enough stocks of books. He also has to deal with a lot of administration and deal with complaints from readers.

No title. We always go to Ireland in June. Every year, the four of us have spent the first fortnight of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a large house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The Malseeds bought the house and have added to it. They have a lot of flowers in the hall. In winter, when no one much comes to Glencorn Lodge, Mrs. Malseed sees to little details like that. In the morning, we'd walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee in the hotel there. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew all that because over the years this kind of pattern had developed.

Keeping the holiday-makers happy is a chalet girl's work. Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a 24-year-old from West Sussex who works as a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. She makes beds and delicious dinners for visitors who come to ski and stay in the chalets.
Sarah's day begins early. She gets up at 7 a.m. and walks to the chalet. She has breakfast and prepares breakfast for the guests. After breakfast, she clears up and makes the afternoon tea. She then goes on the slopes and skis as much as possible.
In the evening, Sarah prepares dinner and takes a shower. She doesn't sleep but stays up to chat with the guests or clean the rooms. Sometimes she will go out with her friends. On Sundays, she has a busy day cleaning and preparing for the new guests.
The work is demanding but Sarah enjoys it. She says, "It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week."

Miss Rita Cohen, a young girl, came to Seymour's factory one day. She was small and had a lot of hair. She was interested in learning about the leather industry. She asked many questions and took notes. Seymour liked finding that she was interested in every last detail. He offered to show her how gloves were made. He told her about the tannery and the history of leather. He also offered to make her a pair of gloves.

Chris Arnot asked four people with dream jobs if they're as wonderful as they seem. A. Raquel Graham is a personal assistant to a pop star. She loves her job and gets on well with her boss, but she can't stand flying. B. David Brown is a golf caddy. He prefers the golf to his accounting job, but there are drawbacks. C. Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. He loves to cook and thinks that expensive restaurants are worth it for those who can afford them. D. Dick Prince is a children's writer. He loves to write and enjoys getting letters from his readers.

In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old brick building two floors high. There was a lot of sawdust around the building. That afternoon, Michael was bored and he climbed up the ladder to the roof of the old building. He jumped off the roof and fell on the sawdust. He lay rolling around and laughing. Some of his friends followed him up to the roof and jumped down. Michael was still on the roof, watching his friends jump down. He was sad and lonely. He stayed on the roof for a long time. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped off the roof. He lay there for a long time. There were no sounds in the yard. He got up slowly and walked home feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everybody.

You are not happy with your job, but you don't know how to change. If you are in this situation, you can turn to a careers adviser. They will ask you to write a brief history of yourself and then give you a summary of the findings and suggest various careers.
Last March, Donna Laney lost her job and decided to go to Career Analysts for help. She was told that she had a gift for design and that she should balance the cost of retraining in design against her financial commitments. Donna decided to use the skills she already had and move into something more suited to her than insurance.
If you are feeling stuck in your job and don't know what to do, you might want to consider going to a careers adviser. However, you should be aware that careers advice doesn't work for everyone.

If you walk into W. Lloyd Jerome's dental surgery in the centre of Glasgow, you'll see bright modern paintings on the wall and a fashionable blue couch. Jerome says that many people are afraid to go to the dentist when they're not in pain. To counteract this, he has tried to create an environment where people are not afraid. He has taken steps to make the surgery more relaxing, such as using virtual-reality headsets and playing videos. He also wants people to smell pleasant things when they walk into the surgery. The surgery smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's. Today there is the smell of orange. The quality of the treatment is of course the most important thing. For example, Jerome uses a special instrument which sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them, rather than scraping them.

**
Chocolate, which has its origins in South America, is a popular treat in many countries. It is made from cacao beans, which are found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies and South-East Asia. The cacao tree is evergreen and produces a fruit that contains seeds. These seeds are dried and become cacao beans. Cacao beans can be used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans. The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and also made a drink called xocoatl. The Spanish found the drink more palatable and spread it to Europe. Chocolate houses were set up in Europe's capital cities where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, chocolate was made from solid blocks of chocolate which had to be melted down in hot water. But in 1826, chocolate powder was invented and the age of the chocolate bar began. Today, chocolate intake in Britain has stabilised at about four bars each week.

Peter Cooke is a shell artist who is known for his unique and delicate creations. He has been making beautiful objects out of shells for the past ten years. His work is admired for its attention to detail, color gradations, and symmetry.
Cooke collects dead shells from all over the world. He travels to beaches in France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines to find the perfect shells. He only collects dead shells and defends himself against people who accuse him of stripping the world's beaches.
Cooke's art is a testament to his creativity and skill. His work is a long way from the common shell constructions that can be found in seaside shops. It is a unique and beautiful art form that has captured the hearts of many people.

When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not flying to wonderful locations or appearing on the covers of magazines, she is usually revising for her school exams. One day, the receptionist at the agency told Jane Laidlaw that Kira would be late. Jane was trying to convince herself that all the bad things she had read about models were rubbish, but the words difficult, vain and unintelligent kept coming into her head. When Kira arrived, she was smiling, relaxed and apologetic. She was not dressed in expensive-looking designer clothes but in a simple black dress and trainers. Kira explained that all models under the age of 16 must take an adult with them whenever they work. She won easily and the Select model agency in London immediately offered her work. Now, Kira has to manage her two separate lives. She has a lot of friends and teachers who are proud of her success, but there are also a few unkind people at her school who are rude about her success. However, Kira is not letting her success get her down. She is confident and has a bright future ahead of her.

Father and son, Terence and Chris Madden, travelled from Canada to Africa to find gold. They have a mine on the side of a Welsh mountain that could contain up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging, they are convinced that they are close to a five million dollar vein of gold.
The pair have dedicated their lives to the hunt for gold. They started their search after the father read about pockets of gold worth millions of pounds buried in the 'Dolgellau gold belt'. Since they started digging, they have spent the past ten years getting permission for their work, taking samples of the earth and removing old cars and rubbish.
Now they are running short of money. They will have to convince a backer to put PS50,000 into the project to lower the mine just a few more metres to where the gold lies.
The Welsh gold industry has gone into steep decline since its height in the late 1880s. However, individual gold-diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to drive a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies chemical processes happening in the sea. She teaches and does research into marine geochemistry. She is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she dives down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
The dive can last for 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to gather samples of rock and water, and then three hours to get back up to the surface.
When Rachel isn't at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two thirds of her salary comes from teaching, which she loves.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry and tanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body and mind couldn't handle any more punishment. I was tired of foreign timetables, currencies and languages. I said, "Never again," as I stepped onto home ground. The train ticket allowed me to travel freely throughout Europe. Ordinary beds are never the same once you've slept in the corridor of a train. Carrying all your possessions on your back in a rucksack makes you have a very basic approach to travel. It encourages incredible wastefulness that can lead to burning socks and getting rid of books when finished. But this way of looking at life is entirely in the spirit of Inter-Rail. All it takes is one of those tickets in your hand. You can travel through countries at a rate of more than one a day. The excitement of travel comes from the sudden reality of somewhere that was previously just a name. It is as if the city in which you arrive never actually existed until the train pulls in at the station and you are able to see it with your own tired eyes for the first time.

There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport overseas and finding that your baggage has been left behind. If your luggage is not there, you may have to wear the clothes you stand up in for hours or days. Sometimes, the airline may not be able to find your luggage, and you may be forced to wear unsuitable clothes in a different climate zone.
The baggage system can fail for many reasons. Sometimes, there are extra security checks at airports or problems with air traffic. There can also be human error or an accident in which the destination label is torn off. These problems can become severe at large transfer airports. Last year, for example, London's Heathrow airport handled more than 41 million passengers, of whom nine million were changing planes.
If your luggage goes missing, you should contact the appropriate airline official in the baggage hall and complete a property irregularity report (PIR). This must be done before leaving the airport.

The kingfisher is a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers. It feeds on fish. The bird cuts like a laser through the scene, straight and fast. It has gone in a split second, but a trace of the image lingers. Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers at an early age. He spent all the time he could by a kingfisher-rich woodland stream. He missed lessons, becoming what he describes as an 'academic failure'. But his interest in this, the world's most widespread kingfisher and the only member of its cosmopolitan family to breed in Europe, was getting noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. Work as an assistant to the editor followed, then a gradual move to life as a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Conducting an orchestra is challenging. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.
A. Anne Manson was asked to help on an opera the next season. She was nervous at first, but she was able to take the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado.
B. Andrew Constantine won a major competition in 1991. He is finding it difficult to lose the 'competition' label.
C. Wasfi Kani loves the long practice period which is part of any opera production. She started conducting seriously in her late twenties.
D. Roger Vignoles started out as a resident musician with an opera house. He was asked to direct Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival.
E. Wayne Marshall was noticed by a conductor in 1986. He found himself conducting a musical in London at short notice.

If you're thinking of taking children to a theme park in Britain, there are many to choose from. We asked five families to test the best. Fun Island, Wonderland, Adventure World, The Great Park, and Fantasy World are all popular theme parks in Britain. Each park has its own unique attractions.
At Fun Island, there are rides for younger children, such as the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There's also a special dodgems ride for the very young kids. For older children, there are scarier rides, such as Splash Out.
At Wonderland, there are rides for all ages, including the Mountain Train, Little Land, and the ferris wheel. The landscaping is perfect and the staff are very helpful and friendly.
At Adventure World, there are rides for all ages, including the Big Top Circus, the Terror Line, and Running River. The park is well designed and the staff are great.
At The Great Park, there are rides for younger children, such as Exotic Travels and Lightning River. The park is clean and the staff are friendly.
At Fantasy World, there are rides for all ages, including the Rocket, the Hanger, and the Long Slide. The park is large and there is a lot to see and do.

Five women talk about their experiences setting up a business in the countryside. They have different businesses, but they all enjoy being independent and having more control over their work hours.
A. Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business. She has a lot of customers and she can work from home.
B. Maggy Sasanow works from home as a designer of greetings cards. She has a big room upstairs and she gets work from all over the world.
C. Delia Turner runs a curtain-making business. She has seen good times and bad times, but she is still working hard.
D. Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business. She enjoys being able to work when she wants to and she publishes books from all over the world.
E. Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business. She started small and has grown her business to be very successful.

Meet the Watkins family. They are musicians. The sons are composers and prize-winning musicians, while Dad makes the instruments. One day, John Watkins needed to get his son, Paul, a cello. He decided to make one himself. He took evening classes and learned to make instruments. Paul was very happy with his dad's cello. He won a competition and was appointed principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. Now, Paul has a new cello that is even better than his dad's. He is going to play the cello in a concert soon.

The National Trust is an organisation that conserves the British countryside. Gareth Roberts is a warden employed by the Trust to look after the beautiful areas it owns. To be a National Trust Warden, you need to have common sense and be good at handling people. Gareth was born and bred on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he married. He has come to understand more about nature conservation since he has been with the Trust. Conservation is one of the main aspects of Gareth's work. His role is to make sure jobs get finished, with as little fuss and as economically as possible.

Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is captain of England's netball team. She had a typical day for the weeks leading up to the World Championships. She taught at a local school and had a training session in the local supermarket car park.
Kendra is very focused when she is playing. She doesn't see anything else except her movements and her feet. She also says that playing netball has become harder and faster.
The World Championships will be tough. There will be a lot of pressure on the England team. But Kendra is confident that they can win.
The England team's first game is against Barbados. They have always beaten Barbados, but this game will be exciting. The team is currently ranked fourth in the world.
Kendra is proud of her career and she is excited about her last big event. She is more than likely to have a tear in her eye when she leads out her team in the opening candlelight ceremony.

A child who shows outstanding musical ability may benefit from the education offered by a specialist music school. Specialist music schools in Britain provide a sympathetic environment for gifted children aged between seven and eighteen to develop their skills to the full under the guidance of professional musicians. Children at specialist music schools spend a significant amount of time on musical activities, including individual lessons, orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting and theory. They also spend several hours a day practising in properly equipped private rooms. The rest of their time is taken up with a restricted academic programme, which concentrates on the essential subjects.
What are the disadvantages of attending a specialist music school?

Artist Susan Shepherd is known for her flower paintings. She has a large garden that is full of her favourite flowers, mostly tulips and poppies. Some of the plants are unruly and seed themselves all over the garden. There is a harmony of colour, shape and structure in the flower borders that line the paved path. Much of this is due to the previous owners who were keen gardeners. Susan prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole. More usually, she picks them and then takes them up to her studio. Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips and poppies are out. She has a come-what-may attitude to the garden, rather like an affectionate aunt who is quite happy for children to run about undisciplined.

Keeping the holiday-makers happy is a chalet girl's work. Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a 24-year-old from West Sussex who works as a chalet girl in Val d'lsere, France. She makes beds and delicious dinners for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets.
Sarah's day begins early. She gets up at 7 a.m. and prepares breakfast for the guests. After breakfast, she clears up and prepares the afternoon tea. She then goes on the slopes and skis as much as possible. In the evening, she prepares dinner, takes a shower, and chats with her friends.
On Sundays, Sarah has a busy day. She starts cleaning early and prepares tea for the new guests. If she hasn't already done the week's shop, she does it now. After cleaning and preparing tea, she takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop and gets a lift back to the chalet. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a chat with friends.

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent the day at the office of a magazine. She went to a photo studio, press previews, and a fashion shoot. She also spent time cuddling animals at the zoo. Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant, spent the day at London Zoo. She stroked an elephant and thought about her future career. Karen Hodson, a nurse, went on location with a television gardening programme. She was excited to be in the fresh air and felt strong despite her hard work. Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener, worked a shift at the hospital. He made beds and handed out tablets. Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent the day with the airline Ryanair as a member of the cabin crew. She felt different in her uniform and wished she was back in the gym. Sonia McDermott, an air hostess, spent the day as a personal trainer in a gym. She was surprised by the amount of attention given to one person and felt satisfied with her job.

On the rails, five celebrities tell Andrew Morgan their favourite memories of railway journeys. Andrea Thompson, a newsreader, fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and tries to get back there as often as she can. There's a local train from Cannes along the coast which crosses the border with Italy. It takes you past some of the most amazing seascapes. The travellers themselves are always lively because there is an interesting mix of tourists and locals, all with different itineraries but all admirers of the breathtaking journey.
Raj Patel, an explorer, has enjoyed so many rail journeys through the years, but if he had to pick a favourite, it would be the Nile Valley Express, which runs across the desert of northern Sudan. The one misfortune in his youth, growing up in South Africa, was missing out on a family train journey from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park.
Betty Cooper, a novelist, is indebted to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took her and her husband on their honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. The journey itself was lovely and the dress she wore on the train was a gift from her husband.
Martin Brown, a journalist, was working on a series of articles based on a round-the-world trip and had to cross a dessert in an African country. There wasn't a road, so the only way to continue their journey was to take the Desert Express. The train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes he had ever seen.
Arisu Mezuki, an actress, imagines most people's favourite impressions of trains and railways are formed when they are young children, but that's not her case. She was brought up in Singapore and Cyprus, where she saw very few trains, let alone travelled on them. It wasn't until she was a teenager that trains began to dominate her life.

If you want to get your story published, you need to do some research and practice your writing skills. You should find out about publishers and markets, and read everything you can about the writing game. To be successful, you need to develop a knowledge of the markets you are aiming at and write well. If you have only written one story or one article, it is not likely to be published. If you want to become a successful writer, you need to write a lot and keep practicing. You should also join a local writers' group or take a creative writing course.

No Title
I was waiting at the Baltimore railway station for the 10.10 to Philadelphia. There were a lot of people waiting. The station was not clean and polished like it usually is. There were elderly couples and college kids waiting. A man was walking around talking to different strangers. He looked well-off. He went up to a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. He came over to me and asked me if I was travelling to Philadelphia. I said yes, but he didn't ask me to go with him. I understood why he didn't. He was probably busy. He was looking seriously stressed. He asked a woman to help him. She was older than me. She agreed to help him. The man was holding a packet. It looked like it was stapled shut. I warned the woman about the packet.

John Moore, a restaurant owner, writes about his relationship with his son Gary, a famous TV chef. Gary was given a chance to shine in the kitchen, and his father was proud of his success.
When John heard about an opportunity, he rushed to look at the place. It was in a really bad state, but it was perfect for what he had in mind. He dedicated himself to running the business and his wife took care of the children and the accounts. They lived over the restaurant and always put a lot of emphasis on having meals together.
Gary was a lively child and he loved to cook. He started working for pocket money and by the age of ten he was in the kitchen every weekend. He was disciplined and he always had loads of money at school.
When Gary was older, he went to catering college and he was successful. He was helping other people out and he was proud of his accomplishments.
John is proud of his son and he thinks that Gary has achieved a lot. He believes that if you work hard, you can achieve anything you want.

Finding a good flat in Dublin was like finding gold in the gold rush. If you knew someone who knew someone who was leaving a place, that often worked. But if you had just arrived in Dublin, there was no chance of any personal contact. You had to stay in a hostel and search.
Jo felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she got on the train to go and work there. She didn't ask herself why she was going there in the first place. She was heading off on her own.
There was a hostel in Dublin that Jo stayed in. It was run by nuns and it was warm. The flat was not in the basement, it was upstairs. And there was a cheerful-looking girl with a college scarf, obviously a failed applicant, coming down the stairs.
Nessa was a cheerful-looking girl with a college scarf. She said they were just about to have a mug of tea. She produced three mugs; one had 'Nessa' and one had 'Pauline' and the other one had 'Other' written on it.

Dolphins are popular animals that people love to see. They are intelligent and sensitive to human emotions. They also allow us to dream of freedom. However, dolphins are facing a number of threats, including pollution, overfishing, and human disturbance.
The main cause of death for dolphins is being caught in fishermen's nets. This is because porpoises have to find their food within a limited time. If fish in one area are removed by fishing, they may not survive long enough to find food elsewhere. Dolphins also suffer from pollution and other substances found in the sea. One example is pesticides. These poisons are soluble in fat, which means that the dolphins can digest them and they can build up in their bodies.
Dolphins live in groups and receive information about much of their world through sound. In the sea, noise pollution - from ships, oil wells and so on - is transmitted four times more efficiently than in the air. This may disturb the dolphins in ways that we do not yet understand.

Getting fit is important for your mind, body and spirit. It's a great way to stay healthy and maintain a perfect balance. There are many reasons why you should exercise. It improves muscle tone and strength, helps you to maintain good posture, and prevents injuries. It also helps to ease depression and tiredness, regulate sleep patterns, and control stress. If you're not sure what type of exercise is best for you, you should consult your doctor. To improve your posture, you need to stretch regularly. Stretching helps you to improve flexibility and ease of movement, and helps you to maintain correct posture and prevent muscle tears and injuries caused by overuse. If you stretch four or five times a week, you'll definitely see the benefits. The best exercise involves a good warm-up, stretching exercises, an energetic workout and definitely a cool down period.

In their natural habitat, film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman are often away from their home comforts for months on end. They are searching for the perfect shot. Two of the hardest creatures to track down in East Africa are Amanda and Owen. Their present habitat, the Ngorongoro Crater, has been affected by a lot of rain. They had to invest in an expensive piece of equipment to help them when their vehicles get stuck in the mud. Their partnership has created some of TV's finest wildlife films. They are often travelling to remote areas to film exotic wildlife. They have learned to set aside four months on location to gather sufficient material for each half-hour film.

Suzie Ellis went to meet England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is captain of England's netball team. She had a typical day for the weeks leading up to the World Championships. She taught at a local school and had a training session in the local supermarket car park.
Kendra is very focused on her training. She said, "My whole life now is all about making sure I'm at my absolute best for the Championships." She is on a strict timetable to gain maximum fitness for the Championships.
The World Championships will be tough. There will be a lot of pressure on the team. But Kendra is confident that they can win. She said, "You don't do all that training not to come out a winner."
Netball is also taking a far more scientific approach to fitness testing. Kendra said, "It is essential that we all think and train like world-class players."
As captain, Kendra has a strong mental attitude and leads by example. She said, "From the very beginning, my netball career has always been carefully planned." So she took the decision some time ago that this competition would be the end of it as far as playing is concerned.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies chemical processes happening in the sea. She teaches and does research into marine geochemistry. She is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she isn't teaching, she dives down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
A dive can last for 16 hours. If there is a problem, you can hit a panic button and the escape vessel will be released. No-one has tested it yet, but it would be a very unpleasant journey.
When Rachel isn't at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. Two thirds of her salary comes from teaching. She loves teaching, but she does it so she can get on with her research.
The only time Rachel has been frightened is when she first went down with the Americans. There was an explosion and she thought, "I'm going to die." But she was still alive.
It's such an adventure diving down to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time Rachel looks out of the porthole and sees the underwater volcanoes, there is such a sense of wonder.

First impressions are often lasting ones. People form impressions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They observe our dress, eye contact, body movement, voice volume and tone, and words.
Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and was confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. However, she didn't get the job. The Head Teacher said that someone who doesn't take the time to present their best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?
Many people ignore the importance of having a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked as an administrative assistant and was not given an interview because she didn't fit the image of an office manager.
Finally, a consideration of what we say and how we say it will contribute to the success of an interview. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests that it's a good idea to inform yourself about the company before you go for an interview.

Matt Froggatt used to be an insurance agent but now runs a sheep farm. He was made redundant and decided to set up the farm. He is glad he is no longer stuck in the office but he still has a lot of work.
Ron Able white was a manager in advertising but now makes a living as an artist. He decided to take redundancy and become an artist. He is happier now and feels less stressed.
Katherine Goodison set up her own business making hats for private clients. She left her job as a lawyer because she wanted to have a better work-life balance. She is happier now and feels less stressed.
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur. He was unhappy with his job and decided to change careers. He is happier now and feels more in control of his destiny.

Four young sports stars talk about their lives. They are all dedicated to their sports. They have to make sacrifices to be successful.
Darius is a runner. He has to train hard and be disciplined. He also has to give up late-night parties.
Gabriel is a surfer. He has to cut out late-night parties and give up lie-ins. He also has to be serious and professional.
Dieter is a yacht racer. He has to be traditional and celebrate wins in great style. He also has to be careful about his health and well-being.
Tomas is a tennis player. He has to travel a lot and be serious and professional. He also has to make sacrifices in his personal life.

Young shoppers at the supermarket often make a lot of demands. They want everything they see. If it's not the latest cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually, all three. Parents often have a lot of trouble managing their children's shopping demands. They feel guilty about buying and feeding them rubbish. And they get cross and defensive in anticipation as they leave home.
Research has found that children taken on a supermarket trip make a purchase request every two minutes. A lot of money is now spent on advertising directly to children, most of it on television. Parents are concerned about what they give their children to eat and have ideas about what food is healthy - although those ideas are not always accurate.
Parents also admit they are inconsistent, even hypocritical, in their responses to their children's purchasing requests. They refuse to buy their children the sweets they want on the grounds that it's bad for them while they are busy loading the trolley with double cream and chocolate for themselves.
Supermarkets could do a lot more to ease parent-child conflict by removing sweets from checkout areas or even by providing supervised play areas.

The Merrion Hotel is a five-star hotel that has recently opened in Dublin. It is a new hotel that has been created using four large eighteenth-century houses. The hotel has a lot of technology, including a computer system that can deal with return clients and a system that controls room temperature. The hotel also has a lot of amenities, such as a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, and restaurants.
The Merrion Hotel is likely to be successful because of its technology, its amenities, and its highly capable staff.

I get my energy from doing things I enjoy. I believe in what I'm doing, both at work and at home. If I'm doing something that I like, I feel good. I also get energy from being around people and communicating with them. If I'm feeling low, I try to do something that makes me happy.
I have a lot of work to do, but I enjoy it all. I love being at work, it isn't a chore. If you enjoy something, it doesn't make you feel low even though you may be feeling tired. I need a fair bit of sleep so when I do get it, I feel really good. When I'm running at six hours' sleep a night, I feel a bit wet. I know exercise gives me energy, but it's finding the energy to do it! I do a yoga class once a week before work and I try to do a workout tape at home. But if I've done exercise, my spirits rise amazingly.
I also get energy from being sociable and from making a garden. If I'm feeling low, I try to do something that makes me happy, such as taking photographs or writing words for imaginary songs.

Ice skating has a long history. People have been skating for thousands of years. In the past, people used skates made from animal bone. Nowadays, skating is both graceful and physically demanding. To skate, you need to be relaxed and have good balance and control. You also need to know how to fall safely. If you can keep this up for a while, you can then slowly increase the length of your movements as you gain experience. There are different styles of skating, but the basic figures can be learned with proper guidance. Skating improves balance, coordination, relaxation and movement. It also improves heart and lung activity and generally strengthens the body. Combined with swimming or jogging, it provides a great programme for all-round health and fitness.

There is a story about some young children who have achieved great success in their chosen fields.
A young girl named Julia won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to become a physiotherapist and compete at the next Olympics.
Another young girl named Sarah made her first show-jumping appearance at ten and has won the British National Championship. She loves show-jumping events and is determined to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team and win a gold medal at the Olympics.
A young girl named Jane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. She loves playing chess and is well-organized.
These children are all examples of how hard work and determination can lead to great success.

Chris Greener was tall when he was fourteen. He is the tallest man in Britain today. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe grows another centimetre. More and more people are being born who are very tall. This does not mean that humanity is producing a new super race. We are returning to what we were like as cavemen. Our ancestors used to eat a wide variety of foods, but today we mostly eat three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice and maize. This poor diet has had a disastrous effect on human health and physique. From then on, agriculture spread because it could support more people. However, the fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been tackled. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm.

Studio audiences are a common feature of television life. They are made up of people from all classes, professions and income groups. People often go to studio audiences to appear on television, take a look behind the scenes, or simply have fun.
When you sit in a studio audience, you are squashed among strangers and someone flashes cards with APPLAUD or LAUGH on them. You clap or laugh accordingly. This may reflect the reality of some television, but not all by any means.
Going to a studio may be a terrible way to watch television, but that's not what's important. For most of the audience, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.

Bruce likes landscapes that have a human element. He finds it important to have people in the landscape. When he was young, he would cycle to a village in England called Lastingham. He loved exploring the hills and valleys. He also found the landscape familiar because he was from Scotland. He wrote about his adventures in his private diary. That was his first attempt at travel writing.
Sophia loves a miniature railway that goes from Hythe to Dungeness. She always travels first class. The scenery is not spectacular. But there is one point on the journey that she always looks forward to - when the train goes through back gardens. She sees herself in the eyes of the people who live in the houses.
Matthew likes the Hartland Peninsula. The beaches are hard to reach and scattered with rocks. There are coast walks which you can combine with trips inland up beautiful damp valleys.
Annette's favourite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It's a landscape of wide-open moorland which is perfect for hiking. There are not many residents and not many visitors either.
James purchased Glenthorne, his favourite house in Britain. It's a magic, secluded, romantic house. You can't hear anything except sea, wind and birds.

We love animals. One day, my daughter found a pine snake. We decided to keep it overnight. We set up a special tank for the snake. It was pouring and the snake escaped. I was able to capture the snake. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer and the snake relaxed. I eventually released the snake back into the wild.

In our fast-paced world, letter writing is at risk of disappearing. But to me, there is something special about receiving a letter that cannot be matched by any other form of communication. It's the excitement of its arrival, the pleasure of seeing who it is from and, finally, the enjoyment of the contents. Letter writing has been part of my life for as long as I can remember. It probably began with the little notes I would write to my mother. My mother also always insisted I write my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday presents. It didn't matter how short or untidy they were as long as they were letters. When I left home to train as a doctor in London, I would write once a week, and so would my mother. I have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. I also write letters to my family and friends. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are appreciated, but it's better to have a year's supply of news! And it's better still when it's an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps.

Tens of thousands of ancient pictures carved into the rocks at one of France's most important tourist sites are being damaged. The drawings include pictures of cows with horns, cultivated fields and various gods and goddesses. But as the popularity of the site increases, the pictures are being ruined by thoughtless graffiti.
The drawings are being damaged rapidly and will not survive for future generations. People are stamping on the drawings, wearing away the rock and definition of the artwork as they do so. Some visitors even chop off parts to take home as souvenirs.
Experts are divided over the best way to preserve the drawings. Some believe that the only way to save the site is to turn the whole mountain into a 'no-go' area. Others want to let people look at the site but impose rules to prevent damage.
The main problem is financial. There is not enough money to hire enough guards to prevent visitors from damaging the drawings. There may also have to be a charge for visitors.
The drawings are an important part of history and must be preserved for future generations. If we do not take steps to protect them, they will be lost forever.

Parents often have a lot of trouble managing their children's shopping demands. They feel guilty about buying and feeding them rubbish. And they get cross and defensive in anticipation as they leave home.
Research has found that children taken on a supermarket trip make a purchase request every two minutes. A lot of money is now spent on advertising directly to children, most of it on television. Parents are concerned about what they give their children to eat and have ideas about what food is healthy - although those ideas are not always accurate.
Parents also admit they are inconsistent, even hypocritical, in their responses to their children's purchasing requests. They refuse to buy their children the sweets they want on the grounds that it's bad for them while they are busy loading the trolley with double cream and chocolate for themselves.
Supermarkets could do a lot more to ease parent-child conflict by removing sweets from checkout areas or even by providing supervised play areas.

Going up the wall was a popular activity in the past. Now, climbers can have a challenging climb anywhere, indoors or out. The crowd holds its breath when climbers are high above them on the climbing wall. The climbing wall is more famous for staging the TV show Gladiators, but it also shares at least one feature with the World Cup Climbing Championships - The Wall. The development of new technology has made it possible to build climbing walls that are similar to the ones found in nature. Before, climbers had to practice their skills on cliffs or use brick-edges or stone buildings to 'work out'. Now, climbers can use interchangeable fixtures to add new holds to any existing wall.

If you want to be an actor, it's a very risky career. There are a lot of actors, but not enough jobs. If you choose to become an actor, many people will tell you you're crazy. But it's a very personal choice and only you can take responsibility for yourself and your ambition. There are no easy ways of getting there, but there is a demand for new faces and new talent. Acting is all about talent and imagination. If you have the talent and the courage, you can become an actor.

We have a selection of cookbooks that are perfect for all skill levels. There's Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course, which has become the kitchen reference book for the modern cook. It has hundreds of easy-to-follow recipes and provides clear instructions on all aspects of basic and more advanced cookery.
There's also Raymond Blanc's book, Blanc Mange, which is a practical reference book with over 80 amazing recipes. It's perfect for beginners and experienced cooks alike.
If you're interested in traditional French cooking, Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook is a must-have. It contains 100 of the school's most respected recipes and is perfect for celebrating the school's hundredth anniversary.
Finally, Nigel Slater's book, The 30-Minute Cook, is perfect for those who want to create delicious food quickly. It has more than 200 recipes from around the world and is perfect for busy people who want to eat well without spending a lot of time in the kitchen.

Matt Froggatt used to be an insurance agent but now runs a sheep farm. He was made redundant and decided to set up the farm. He is glad he is no longer stuck in the office but he still has a lot of work.
Ron Able white was a manager in advertising but now makes a living as an artist. He decided to take redundancy and become an artist. He is happier now and feels less stressed.
Katherine Goodison set up her own business making hats for private clients. She left her job as a lawyer because she wanted to have a better work-life balance. She is happier now and feels less stressed.
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur. He was unhappy with his job and decided to change careers. He is happier now and feels more in control of his destiny.

**
Two brothers, Dave and Norm Lagasse, are playing a game called pichenotte. It's a game of skill that is popular in Canada and the USA. The game is played on a wooden board with 12 pieces called pucks. The goal is to flick the puck into a hole and score points. The game usually lasts just two minutes.
The Lagasses started making their own boards and selling them to others. They're made of birchwood and mahogany and weigh 12kg. They cost $595 each.
The game is popular and championships are being held. There is a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup'. The Lagasses are happy to spend their off-duty hours playing the game they hope will make their fortune.

The Model Village was once a piece of waste ground that was transformed into a beautiful masterpiece. The village was created by one man named Colin Sims and his wife. They worked hard to change the land into a sculpted landscape. Many tons of soil and clay were moved to create the village. Hundreds of trees and shrubs were also planted. The models in the village are made from a variety of materials, including stone, concrete, and wood. They are very detailed and accurate. The village is popular and has been used as an example of high-quality workmanship.

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that intrude into people's privacy. Although pop stars sometimes pose for paparazzi, this is not typical. More usually, pictures of individuals in the public eye are taken without their consent and published on the front page. Very few people call on the services of the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was set up to deal with issues of this kind. The pictures in the public interest are rarely in the public interest. Do pictures of pop stars help to detect a crime? In what way did the picture of a famous actress on a hotel bedroom balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has made a fuss about long-lens pictures in the past and since she was in a hotel, a place where there is a reasonable expectation of privacy, she had good cause for complaint, but she didn't take any action. The PCC should take the initiative on this and other shameful attacks. To begin with, this seems like a great idea. It would surely lead to many decisions against newspapers. Even photographers would be affected, no longer finding it financially possible to spend their days hidden behind trees waiting to snap unsuspecting celebrities. However, there are also some concerns about taking on this role. How would the PCC decide whether or not to launch an inquiry? And if the person involved still refuses to do anything, should the PCC proceed nevertheless?

A lot of advice is available for college leavers heading for their first job. If you are taking a real step on the career ladder and choosing a job to fit in with your ambitions, you should choose your second job very carefully. You should be aiming to stay in it for two to three years. It should show evidence of serious career planning and extend you, develop you and give you increasing responsibility.
If you are thinking of travelling, now is the time to pack up and go. You can do temporary work for a while when you return, pick up where you left off and get the second job then. Future potential employers will be relieved to see that you have got it out of your system and are not likely to go off again.

Confident people may appear to be born with it, but most will tell you that it's a skill they've learned. Nina Hathway asked five people how they did it.
A Jenny said, "When I left school, I was very shy and I always thought I'd stay that way. But I surprised myself by doing well and someone there suggested that I should do a university course."
B Michaela said, "It all started four years ago when my father became ill and I had to take over the family business. I was so scared, I went over the top and became a bit too aggressive and impatient. But I learned that to be confident, you've got to believe in yourself."
C Lisa said, "People think I'm very confident, but, in fact, the calmer I look, the more terrified I really am. I've had to develop the ability to look confident because it's the most vital thing in TV."
D Barbara said, "My confidence comes naturally from really enjoying the work I do, but it's something that I've built up over the years."
E Kim said, "After I left college, I worked for years as a secretary and would sit in meetings, not always agreeing with what was being said, but too scared to speak up. Eventually, I summoned up the confidence to start making my point."

Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival in Malaysia. He spends a nervous night in the forest. He met a man named Adnan Ali who gave him a traditional kite. The kite was made of tissue paper and split bamboo. It was very big and colorful. They sat down in the shade of the trees and looked at the kites. There was a lot of people at the festival. Many people had registered to compete in the competition. The competition ran for five days. Paul stayed in a hut in the forest. It was a very peaceful place. There was a lot of noise at night. But Paul was not bothered. He woke up early and saw a beautiful view of the mountains. It rained in the afternoon. Paul was wet through. But he was still happy. He went sliding downhill. He wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the enormous drops. He was glad that his car was still there. He went back to Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital. Everyone was friendly. Kelantan is best known for its kites, but Paul remembered it more for its human kindness.

**
What sort of shopper are you? We all go shopping, but there are different types of shopper. Do you know which kind you are? Abby Edwards asked around and found out that there are different types of shoppers. Some people are addicted to shopping, while others are reluctant or even hate it. There are also people who only shop for essentials or those who like to go for a look around.
If you are an addicted shopper, you might be like Abby. You can't spend enough money and you feel miserable when you don't have cash. If you are a reluctant shopper, you might be like Brenda. You don't spend much time shopping for clothes and you feel guilty when you spend money on yourself. If you are an essential shopper, you might be like Juliet. You only shop for essentials and you find shopping tiring. If you are a careful shopper, you might be like Suki. You like going to the shops, but you don't buy very much. If you are an unwilling shopper, you might be like Linda. You don't like shopping and you don't bother to try things on.

**
The Open University offers a degree. You can study at home and attend one class a month at an Open University centre. You can also find new career opportunities if you have a qualification from the Open University. If you would like to know more, you can complete the form below.
